lines.text: Enter CLEOPATRA, DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS, CHARMIAN, and IRAS

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: What shall we do, Enobarbus

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: Think, and die.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Is Antony or we in fault for this

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: Antony only, that would make his will Lord of his reason. What though you fled From that great face of war, whose several ranges Frighted each other why should he follow The itch of his affection should not then Have nickd his captainship at such a point, When half to half the world opposed, he being The meered question: twas a shame no less Than was his loss, to course your flying flags, And leave his navy gazing.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Prithee, peace.
Enter MARK ANTONY with EUPHRONIUS, the Ambassador

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Is that his answer

lines.speaker: euphronius
lines.text: Ay, my lord.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: The queen shall then have courtesy, so she Will yield us up.

lines.speaker: euphronius
lines.text: He says so.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Let her knowt. To the boy Caesar send this grizzled head, And he will fill thy wishes to the brim With principalities.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: That head, my lord

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: To him again: tell him he wears the rose Of youth upon him from which the world should note Something particular: his coin, ships, legions, May be a cowards whose ministers would prevail Under the service of a child as soon As i the command of Caesar: I dare him therefore To lay his gay comparisons apart, And answer me declined, sword against sword, Ourselves alone. Ill write it: follow me.
Exeunt MARK ANTONY and EUPHRONIUS

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: [Aside]  Yes, like enough, highbattled Caesar will Unstate his happiness, and be staged to the show, Against a sworder! I see mens judgments are A parcel of their fortunes and things outward Do draw the inward quality after them, To suffer all alike. That he should dream, Knowing all measures, the full Caesar will Answer his emptiness! Caesar, thou hast subdued His judgment too.
Enter an Attendant

lines.speaker: attendant
lines.text: A messenger from CAESAR.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: What, no more ceremony See, my women! Against the blown rose may they stop their nose That kneeld unto the buds. Admit him, sir.
Exit Attendant

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: [Aside]  Mine honesty and I begin to square. The loyalty well held to fools does make Our faith mere folly: yet he that can endure To follow with allegiance a falln lord Does conquer him that did his master conquer And earns a place i the story.
Enter THYREUS

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Caesars will

lines.speaker: thyreus
lines.text: Hear it apart.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: None but friends: say boldly.

lines.speaker: thyreus
lines.text: So, haply, are they friends to Antony.

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: He needs as many, sir, as Caesar has Or needs not us. If Caesar please, our master Will leap to be his friend: for us, you know, Whose he is we are, and that is, Caesars.

lines.speaker: thyreus
lines.text: So. Thus then, thou most renownd: Caesar entreats, Not to consider in what case thou standst, Further than he is Caesar.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Go on: right royal.

lines.speaker: thyreus
lines.text: He knows that you embrace not Antony As you did love, but as you feard him.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: O!

lines.speaker: thyreus
lines.text: The scars upon your honour, therefore, he Does pity, as constrained blemishes, Not as deserved.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: He is a god, and knows What is most right: mine honour was not yielded, But conquerd merely.

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: [Aside]             To be sure of that, I will ask Antony. Sir, sir, thou art so leaky, That we must leave thee to thy sinking, for Thy dearest quit thee.
Exit

lines.speaker: thyreus
lines.text: Shall I say to Caesar What you require of him for he partly begs To be desired to give. It much would please him, That of his fortunes you should make a staff To lean upon: but it would warm his spirits, To hear from me you had left Antony, And put yourself under his shrowd, The universal landlord.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Whats your name

lines.speaker: thyreus
lines.text: My name is Thyreus.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Most kind messenger, Say to great Caesar this: in deputation I kiss his conquering hand: tell him, I am prompt To lay my crown at s feet, and there to kneel: Tell him from his allobeying breath I hear The doom of Egypt.

lines.speaker: thyreus
lines.text: Tis your noblest course. Wisdom and fortune combating together, If that the former dare but what it can, No chance may shake it. Give me grace to lay My duty on your hand.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Your Caesars father oft, When he hath mused of taking kingdoms in, Bestowd his lips on that unworthy place, As it raind kisses.
Reenter MARK ANTONY and DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Favours, by Jove that thunders! What art thou, fellow

lines.speaker: thyreus
lines.text: One that but performs The bidding of the fullest man, and worthiest To have command obeyd.

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: [Aside]               You will be whippd.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Approach, there! Ah, you kite! Now, gods and devils! Authority melts from me: of late, when I cried Ho! Like boys unto a muss, kings would start forth, And cry Your will Have you no ears I am Antony yet. Take hence this Jack, and whip him.
Enter Attendants

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: [Aside]  Tis better playing with a lions whelp Than with an old one dying.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Moon and stars! Whip him. Weret twenty of the greatest tributaries That do acknowledge Caesar, should I find them So saucy with the hand of she here,whats her name, Since she was Cleopatra Whip him, fellows, Till, like a boy, you see him cringe his face, And whine aloud for mercy: take him hence.

lines.speaker: thyreus
lines.text: Mark Antony!

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Tug him away: being whippd, Bring him again: this Jack of Caesars shall Bear us an errand to him. You were half blasted ere I knew you: ha! Have I my pillow left unpressd in Rome, Forborne the getting of a lawful race, And by a gem of women, to be abused By one that looks on feeders
Exeunt Attendants with THYREUS

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Good my lord,

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: You have been a boggler ever: But when we in our viciousness grow hard O misery ont!the wise gods seel our eyes In our own filth drop our clear judgments make us Adore our errors laugh ats, while we strut To our confusion.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: O, ist come to this

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: I found you as a morsel cold upon Dead Caesars trencher nay, you were a fragment Of Cneius Pompeys besides what hotter hours, Unregisterd in vulgar fame, you have Luxuriously pickd out: for, I am sure, Though you can guess what temperance should be, You know not what it is.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Wherefore is this

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: To let a fellow that will take rewards And say God quit you! be familiar with My playfellow, your hand this kingly seal And plighter of high hearts! O, that I were Upon the hill of Basan, to outroar The horned herd! for I have savage cause And to proclaim it civilly, were like A halterd neck which does the hangman thank For being yare about him. Is he whippd
Reenter Attendants with THYREUS

lines.speaker: first attendant
lines.text: Soundly, my lord.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Cried he and beggd a pardon

lines.speaker: first attendant
lines.text: He did ask favour.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: If that thy father live, let him repent Thou wast not made his daughter and be thou sorry To follow Caesar in his triumph, since Thou hast been whippd for following him: henceforth The white hand of a lady fever thee, Shake thou to look on t. Get thee back to Caesar, Tell him thy entertainment: look, thou say He makes me angry with him for he seems Proud and disdainful, harping on what I am, Not what he knew I was: he makes me angry And at this time most easy tis to dot, When my good stars, that were my former guides, Have empty left their orbs, and shot their fires Into the abysm of hell. If he mislike My speech and what is done, tell him he has Hipparchus, my enfranched bondman, whom He may at pleasure whip, or hang, or torture, As he shall like, to quit me: urge it thou: Hence with thy stripes, begone!
Exit THYREUS

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Have you done yet

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Alack, our terrene moon Is now eclipsed and it portends alone The fall of Antony!

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: I must stay his time.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: To flatter Caesar, would you mingle eyes With one that ties his points

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Not know me yet

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Coldhearted toward me

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Ah, dear, if I be so, From my cold heart let heaven engender hail, And poison it in the source and the first stone Drop in my neck: as it determines, so Dissolve my life! The next Caesarion smite! Till by degrees the memory of my womb, Together with my brave Egyptians all, By the discandying of this pelleted storm, Lie graveless, till the flies and gnats of Nile Have buried them for prey!

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: I am satisfied. Caesar sits down in Alexandria where I will oppose his fate. Our force by land Hath nobly held our severd navy too Have knit again, and fleet, threatening most sealike. Where hast thou been, my heart Dost thou hear, lady If from the field I shall return once more To kiss these lips, I will appear in blood I and my sword will earn our chronicle: Theres hope int yet.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Thats my brave lord!

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: I will be treblesinewd, hearted, breathed, And fight maliciously: for when mine hours Were nice and lucky, men did ransom lives Of me for jests but now Ill set my teeth, And send to darkness all that stop me. Come, Lets have one other gaudy night: call to me All my sad captains fill our bowls once more Lets mock the midnight bell.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: It is my birthday: I had thought to have held it poor: but, since my lord Is Antony again, I will be Cleopatra.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: We will yet do well.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Call all his noble captains to my lord.

lines.speaker: mark antony
lines.text: Do so, well speak to them and tonight Ill force The wine peep through their scars. Come on, my queen Theres sap int yet. The next time I do fight, Ill make death love me for I will contend Even with his pestilent scythe.
Exeunt all but DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS

lines.speaker: domitius enobarbus
lines.text: Now hell outstare the lightning. To be furious, Is to be frighted out of fear and in that mood The dove will peck the estridge and I see still, A diminution in our captains brain Restores his heart: when valour preys on reason, It eats the sword it fights with. I will seek Some way to leave him.
Exit
